heading: Abstract
text: Ticks (Ixodida) represent one important vector groups affecting human animal health, recent years increasing concerns regarding cause tick-borne disease affecting Australians. Worldwide, wildlife health surveillance recognised key tool investigating tick-borne infections One Health approach essential understand epidemiology tick-associated microbes. Therefore, research aimed ; ) identify ticks Australian wildlife; ii) investigate bacteria haemoprotozoa present wildlife ticks; iii) characterise microbes understand interplay host-microbe-tick. Molecular tools used assist identification Australian ticks. Museum specimens human biting tick Amblyomma triguttatum used investigate molecular systematics species complex. set molecular barcodes developed Australian ticks, important accurate identification immature life stages cryptic species. Additionally, novel 12S rDNA metabarcoding assay developed high throughput identification ticks. Free-ranging animals ticks sampled urban peri-urban areas. bacterial haemoprotozoan diversity characterised using combination amplicon high-throughput sequencing, targeted Sanger sequencing, microscopy. Bacterial profiling generated 100 million sequences. Statistical analysis using constrained ordination methods revealed blood, tick tissues distinct community signatures. diverse range tick associated microbes identified, Anaplasmataceae, Bartonellaceae, Borreliaceae, Coxiellaceae, Midichloriaceae. Overall, microbes rare wildlife hosts generally confined specific sample types. addition, eight species haemoprotozoa identified, including species within genera Babesia, Hepatozoon, Theileria Trypanosoma. Lastly, study confirmed absence northern hemisphere tick-borne pathogens provided evidence unique microbes present Australian wildlife ticks.

heading: Preface
text:
Ticks (Acari: Ixodida) group blood-feeding arthropods represent one important vector groups affect human animal health. Almost 900 species tick described globally, 10% documented transmit variety pathogens livestock, companion animals humans (Jongejan Uilenberg 2004).
Ticks can carry diverse range infectious microbes viruses, piroplasms, spirochaetes rickettsiales (Pfaffle et al. 2013).
Tick-borne diseases globally include Lyme borreliosis (Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato), ehrlichiosis (Ehrlichia chaffeensis), babesiosis (Babesia spp.), tick-borne encephalitis (Flavivirus) Powassan disease (Powassan virus).
tick bite can cause local reactions, irritation erythema migrans, cases can induce severe systemic syndromes paralysis, anaphylaxis mammalian meat allergy (Nunen 2015; Beaman 2018; Pienaar, Neitz, Mans 2018).Presently, 74 extant tick species Australia described (S. C. Barker, Walker, Campelo 2014; Ash et al. 2017; Heath Palma 2017; Kwak, Madden, Wicker 2018; D. Barker 2019), eight well known bite humans (Stephen C. Barker Walker 2014).
date three human tick-borne pathogens (TBPs) recognised endemic Australia (S. R. Graves Stenos 2017); Rickettsia australis Rickettsia honei causative agents Queensland tick typhus Australian (Flinders Island) spotted fever, respectively.
third TBP Australia Coxiella burnetii causative agent Q Fever, usually associated tick-bite, ticks play critical role life cycle bacterium.
Despite endemic rickettsial infections recognised Australia, increasing pressure surrounding presence unknown TBP causing illness people bitten Australian ticks.
particular, public concern around ‘Lyme-like’ illnesses gained considerable attention commonwealth senate inquiry held 2016 (Radcliffe et al. 2016).literature review provide brief overview tick systematics tick biology.

heading: 3.2 Introduction
text:
Ticks carry diverse range infectious microbes viruses, piroplasms, spirochaetes Rickettsiales (Pfaffle et al. 2013).
Globally recognised infectious human tick-borne diseases include Lyme borreliosis, ehrlichiosis, babesiosis, tick-borne encephalitis Powassan viral disease.
Additionally, tick bite can cause reactions paralysis anaphylaxis (Van Nunen et al. 2009).

sylvatic cycles tick-borne pathogens northern hemisphere generally well understood respect competent tick vectors reservoir hosts (e.g. Babesia microti (Westblade et al. 2017) Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato (Radolf et al. 2012)).

R. Graves Stenos 2017).

heading: 4.1 Abstract
text:
Vector-borne haemoprotozoans comprise diverse group eukaryote single-celled organisms transmitted haematophagous (blood-feeding) invertebrates.
can cause debilitating diseases impact wildlife, livestock, companion animals humans.
Recent research shown Australian wildlife host diverse range haemoprotozoan species; however, date work primarily confined host species isolated populations rural habitats.
little investigation presence blood parasites wildlife inhabiting urban peri-urban areas.

heading: 5.1 Abstract
text: Invasive rodent species known hosts diverse range infectious microorganisms long associated spread disease globally. present study describes molecular evidence presence Trypanosoma sp. black rats (Rattus rattus) northern Sydney, Australia. Sequences 18S ribosomal RNA (18S rRNA) gene obtained two eleven (18%) blood samples subsequent phylogenetic analysis confirming identity within Trypanosoma lewisi clade.

heading: 5.2 Introduction
text: Black rats (Rattus rattus) distributed throughout world considered one significant invasive species. Current evidence indicates Rattus genus originated Southeast Asia (Aplin et al. 2011), black rats establishing Australia alongside European settlement 1770’s, although precise date first arrival continent unclear (Banks Hughes 2012). Black rats can act amplifying hosts diverse range pathogens can affect humans, wildlife domestic animals recent review black rats Europe identified least 20 zoonotic infectious agents associated species (Strand Lundkvist 2019). However, despite global recognition rodents hosts pathogens, relatively limited understanding range infectious agents present Australian populations black rats (Banks Hughes 2012).Trypanosomes group flagellate protozoan parasites, vast majority transmitted blood-feeding invertebrates. Worldwide least 44 trypanosome species known infect rodents (reviewed Dybing et al. (2016)). Due morphological similarities within Trypanosoma subgenus Herpetosoma (Maia da Silva et al. 2010; Ortiz et al. 2018), records based microscopic observations alone may underestimate diversity trypanosome species infecting rodents; number likely increase frequent application molecular methodologies contemporary studies. Trypanosoma (Herpetosoma) lewisi almost exclusively utilises Rattus sp. host commonly vectored rodent fleas, Xenopsylla cheopis Nosopsyllus fasciatus (Ortiz et al. 2018). members subgenus largely considered non-pathogenic respective hosts, infections identified number mammalian species, including humans (Maia da Silva et al. 2010; Ortiz et al. 2018). heading: 6.2 Introduction
text: Haemoprotozoan parasites unicellular eukaryotic organisms complex lifecycles involving invertebrate vector often alternate tropism tissues blood vertebrate hosts. Four major haemoprotozoan assemblages infect mammals (P. O’Donoghue 2017); () Trypanosomatids (Kinetoplastea), flagellated protists characterised presence unique organelle, kinetoplast; (ii) haemogregarines (Adeleorina); (iii) haemosporidia (Haemosporidia); (iv) piroplasms (Piroplasmida). Broadly haemoprotozoans considered either host specific (e.g. Theileria ornithorhynchi infecting platypus (Ornithorhynchus anatinus) host (. Paparini et al. 2015)) generalists (e.g. Trypanosoma cruzi infects wide range mammals (Clement et al. 2020)). However, true diversity epidemiology species remains unknown.Tasmanian devil, Sarcophilus harrisii, largest extant marsupial carnivore. present across mainland Australia (~3,000 years ago), distribution wild populations Tasmanian devils became restricted island Tasmania (Bruniche-Olsen et al. 2018), southern coast Australian mainland. Biogeographical events influenced declines effective size devil populations distribution, consequential genetic bottleneck resulting low genetic diversity (M. E. Jones et al. 2004; Bruniche-Olsen et al. 2018; Patton et al. 2019). Since 1996, transmissible cancer (devil tumour facial disease, DFTD hereafter) gradually spread across distributional range species caused local population declines upwards 80% (McCallum et al. 2009; Lazenby et al. 2018). Transmission DFTD occurs direct transfer live tumour cells individuals devils bite social interactions (Pearse Swift 2006; Hamede, McCallum, Jones 2013; D. G. Hamilton et al. 2019). Survival DFTD infected individuals usually 6-12 months clinical signs appear; disease lethal almost 100% cases (Pye, Woods, Kreiss 2016). consequence transmission driven social interactions, DFTD still present even largely depleted populations hosts (McCallum et al. 2009). Therefore, additional pressure(s) host health, co-infections haemoparasites, threaten imperilled populations, yet, little known devil’s parasite community (Wait, Peck, et al. 2017).date, four protozoan parasite groups identified wild devil populations; Cryptosporidium spp., Giardia spp., Toxoplasma gondii Sarcocystis sp. previous study identified sporulated sporocysts consistent Sarcocystis (family: Sarcocystidae) species intestinal mucosa using microscopic examination (Munday et al. 1978). north-west Tasmania, T. gondii prevalence higher carnivorous marsupials Tasmanian devil, spotted-tail quoll (Dasyurus maculatus) eastern quoll (D. viverrinus), compared sympatric prey marsupials like brushtail possum (Trichosurus vulpecula), Bennett’s wallaby (Notamacropus rufogriseus, syn. Macropus rufogriseus) Tasmanian pademelon (Thylogale billardierii) (Hollings et al. 2013). Amplicon PCRs carried 25 \(\mu\)L reactions containing: 1X buffer (KAPA Biosystems, South Africa), 2.5 mM MgCl2, 0.4 \(\mu\)M primer, 0.25 mM dNTP, 1 U Taq (KAPA Biosystems, South Africa) 1 \(\mu\)L tick gDNA.Thermal cycling conditions followed; 95\(^\circ\)C 5 mins, followed 5 cycles 95\(^\circ\)C 15 secs, 51\(^\circ\)C 30 secs, 68\(^\circ\)C 30 secs; 25 cycles 95\(^\circ\)C 30 secs, 53\(^\circ\)C 30 secs, 72\(^\circ\)C 1 min; final extension 72\(^\circ\)C 5 mins.Amplicon PCR products indexed using Nextera XT DNA library preparation kit 25 \(\mu\)L volumes following manufacturer’s recommendations.
PCRs included template controls (NTC) reaction set PCRs performed strict laboratory conditions. Amplicons dual-indexed using Nextera XT index kit.
Reactions performed 25 \(\mu\)L volumes using following manufacturers recommendations.
Libraries purified Axygen PCR clean beads, pooled equimolar amounts quantified using Qubit High Sensitivity dsDNA assay kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) amplicons pooled equimolar amounts.
Libraries shipped Australian Genomic Research Facility (Melbourne, Australia) final QC sequenced Illumina MiSeq using v2 chemistry (2 x 250 paired end).

heading: A.1.1.4 Bioinformatics
text:
Multilocus sequence typing data produced Sanger SequencingSequences imported Geneious 10.2.6 (https://www.geneious.com) quality inspection.
Forward reverse sequenced aligned using default parameters Geneious primers trimmed.
Reference sequences retrieved GenBank (Benson et al. 2017) aligned sequences obtained present study using MUSCLE (R. C. Edgar 2004).High-throughout sequence data produced Illumina MiSeqIllumina MiSeq fastq data analysed using bioinformatic pipeline program USEARCH v11 (R. C. Edgar 2010).
Paired end reads merged sequences matching forward reverse primers retrieved (max number mismatches = 2).
Sequences quality filtered singletons removed.
unoise3 (Robert C. Edgar 2016) algorithm used perform denoising (error-correction) generate zero-radius taxonomic units (zOTUs) equivalent amplicon sequence variants (ASVs).
Resulting zOTUs subject BLAST analysis (BLASTN 2.11.0+ (Zhang et al. 2000; Morgulis et al. 2008)) NCBI nucleotide collection (nt) database.
Taxonomic lineage top hit (based e-value score) retrieved NCBI taxonomy database using TaxonKit (Weiss et al. 2021).
Final taxonomy assignment refined lowest common ancestor based BLAST results (percentage identity, e-value query coverage) sequence alignment method.Sequences generated aligned reference sequences retrieved GenBank (Benson et al. 2017) using MAFFT (R. C. Edgar 2004).
Phylogenies inferred using maximum likelihood (ML) method.
optimal evolutionary model selected using ModelFinder (Kalyaanamoorthy et al. 2017) based bayesian information criterion.
Phylogenetic analysis performed IQ-TREE v1.6.11 (Nguyen et al. 2015) bootstrap support calculated using ultrafast (UFBoot2) method 10,000 replicates (Hoang et al. 2018).
Genetic sequence similarity calculated using Kimura Two-Parameter method (Tamura Nei 1993).
